column3: exp_reflect

I do qualitative research and the risk of deanonymizing with full data is too high to make my data easily available. But if the person was nice, I might share a coding table or an unpublished appendix for example. (However, I think the spirit of a lot of these reproduction hunters in areas like psychology is rather unkind and perhaps looking to "take down" female and non-white researchers, so that's also a consideration especially if the topic is controversial.)

Generally, I'd be inclined to share the data and code, but it depends on a) who the other researcher is (are they credible, do I know them) and b) whether I would be allowed to share the data and c) where allowed to share the data whether I am still working on a follow up paper, in which case I would share the materials once that paper is in the public domain.

It sounds like they are trying to disprove me. They're on a witch hunt. There's a good chance they are doing this to a lot of people and are, themselves, going to suffer from a file drawer problem. If they re-run 100 people's studies and find that 1 doesn't replicate, that's the one they will publish and descredit and shame the researcher, ignoring the fact that it was likely due to chance, and not noting the 99 who got it right.

Unless the data are proprietary with a nondisclosure agreement, I do not see a reason not to share. For code, it depends on whether I think the person is trying to replicate, or if they just want code because they are too lazy or lack the skill to do it themselves.
I belive in the reproducibility of science experiments. This is how science evolve
It depends if the data is proprietary
I think that a study should be reviewed after publication and "corrected" if there are arguments for this.

I am working with qualitative data, mostly from ethnographic research. My main concern is that I so far do not see a way of anonymising or pseudonymising a whole data set comprising interview, observation, and document data. Publicly sharing this data violates privacy and data protection rules.

I want to help others and sharing data and code can help generate citations to my work. Additionally, refusing to share can carry risks that the requestor will try to stir up controversy around your findings and accuse you of misconduct. However, I would be hesitant to share broadly versus narrowly (i.e., to only the requestor) to avoid helping researchers who will try to undercut my work or use my data and code to create competing research papers that will hurt my publication chances on follow-up studies. I also do not want to help researchers who have previously harmed me and my research.

Code can be easily shared. With the data, which might be proprietary, can be more problematic. Also, I would have to be certain that the person making the request seems ok, that there is a genuine interest in improving something, and not just laziness on gathering the data or coding, or some more obscure purpose. That is, I would expect a sound letter from this person explaining what they plan to do with whatever they are requesting.

If I have put in hours and hours of effort hand collecting data, I do not believe I am under any responsibility to give away the competitive advantage I developed from all that effort. If people have to give away their hand-collected data, fewer people will do it.
I think this is good research practice and would like to answer 100%.  My level of trust in my peer researchers is quite a bit lower than that (I have seen too much) hence the 80% overall.
Confident tax data

It depends how recent is the publication. I am generally open to sharing my code but a) I am not sure I can find the code for something published 20 years ago b) I would be reluctant to share something that is part of an active research program c) the code is often written by a co-author.

I usually work with comercial data, e.g. from compustat or IBES, which I must not provide to a third party. In addition, I do not see the use of providing code to a third party. If a researcher cannot replicate my empirical results, this should be clarified together with me or my co-authors.
Replication, extension, etc are important for a healthy functioning scientific discipline.
I don't want to have a paper that corrects my paper :)
It depends on (1) how I am approached ("friendly" or "unfriendly" tone of mail/request) and (2) potentially the "status"/name of the individual approaching me (or at least his/her affiliation).

I chose 75% percent because, in principle, I am in favor of making any research-related items public. However, there could be circumstances where this could be impossible (if data is protected) or undesirable for the researcher in the short run (e.g., where intensive data collection was done by hand). The latter is a tricky case because not making material available can hinder the scientific process. Therefore, I support the approach by some journals (like Management Science) to have a disclosure moratorium of a few years. One might be hesitant to share code because others could discover coding errors.

if data is from public sources:  i will not send the data but will share how data/variables were computed.  May send part or all of the code. .  If data is proprietary: I will not share the data but will provide information regarding the code/computation. May send part or all of the code
Data might be proprietary, so I might not be allowed to share it. Code can always be shared.
It depends on who the scholar is. I'd rather have the Journal ask me about all this material and make it public in an official site.
I will be happy to share with reasonable researchers. in case I will use the (proprietary) data for further studies, I may hold it after till further studies are published.
I don't have anything to hide. My data is also not sensitive (I do experiments; it's not like one would use the exact same data for a follow-up paper)
it's easy to do and potentially advances science/discovery, feel responsibility to other researchers, norms of science

In general, I fully agree that we should do this.  In specific cases, if I would be asked, my response would depend on:  - the confidentiality of the data  - the required effort to bring the data/code into a form that it can be shared (i.e., the effort for cleaning, anonymizing etc.)  - the credibility/standing of the researcher that requests the data (I would probably not share the data and code with a person I have never heard about and who has never published in a respectable journal)
To prove research integrity of my work. To generate traction with (and increase visibility of) my published work.

No problem sharing research materials, so long as they can be anonymized.  I worry about sharing the actual data, as some of it could be qualitative and more difficult to anonymize.  Would need to make sure we conform with confidentiality agreements with participating individuals and organizations.
research expansion.
Depends on the paper - if the data is publicly available or self-collected, I would be more likely to do it.

I did not say 100% as I think there is a chance I may not share my data in the case that I believe this is not a request coming from a 'real' person/researcher (like a bot or similar). Otherwise, I see no impediment. Hopefully, they find the data/code/instrument useful.
I think her request is reasonable
It depends on whether I believe the request is a credible request.
I very often use hand-collected data, and these are used for multiple projects.

I would generally agree to share codes and data. In some cases, however the original data might have implied high collection costs and been protected by legal agreement. If that was the case, I would agree on sharing some ready to use measures but not the original data
one must share these materials upon request, it's the premise of the scientific process
I would feel obligated to comply completely
Qualitative data are confidential. Ethics approval strongly restricts access to data by others.
Important to let people replicate the results and build on my research to create new insights
low cost
NA
As long as the data agreement allows sharing, data should be shared. Code & supplemental information should be shared anyways, especially upon request.
There are times when the data that I use was obtained under a license. If so, I cannot share the data unless the researcher has access to the underlying data themselves.
Would always respond if the researcher a[[eared to be reputable
avoid risk of being criticized
I would need to have additional information regarding their use of the materials.
I would likely share the material, but I would want to know more about the nature of their request.
My data includes confidential materials collected through interviews and internal company documents such as personal e-mails etc., sharing would constitute a huge problem with the case company.
We should have more replication studies in accounting
Transparency in research is a good thing.

I have shared my instruments 100% of the time I have been asked, no questions asked. I've shared my code with a few colleagues to show them how I tackled something re: variables or analyses but no one has ever asked for all of my code or for my data. So that feels a little more unusual. Honestly, I don't have anything to hide but it still feels suspicious or like an intrusion. I don't know why I feel that way, it just feels a little more personal. I'm pretty sure I would eventually say yes but I likely would ask to clarify why they need data and code (on top of instrument) before handing it over. For a request for the instrument, my reply email would include the instrument as an attachment. For a request for the other stuff, my reply email probably wouldn't include those attachments, but could on follow-up.
My belief in research is that it should be collaborative, something that can be replicated, and transparent as much as possible.

Generally I will (and have) shared the research data, either upon request or by default. In case I would be working on a follow-up study with the same data, I may be more reluctant to immediately share the data.
As long as I understand the purpose of the request, I am likely to comply with the request.
NA
We serve the public

I'm a strong believer in "open source" research. When in control of projects, I have made code and data available. (Mind you, generally co-authors have a say and do not want to share.) I have a lot of experience in replicating papers. In most cases replication is only really possible with access to code and data. Papers after ~2000 generally are very fragile.
It is good to do it
I would first like to know what the concerns are, such that I could learn from the process as well.

Many academics, including me, are constantly working under high pressure to deliver performance and  short of time to fulfill a large range of commitments. It is simply impossible to entertain each and every such request, especially when replying to the first might lead to feeling the obligation to answer more questions from the requester in the future. A requester can be a relatively inexperienced graduate student exploring a doctoral topic, which has implications to how many questions s/he might have in the future. Thus, the propensity to reply to a request often depends on the status of the requester in the field and the anticipated consequences (or the lack of) of entertaining the request (or not).
Concerns over anonymity of data
I would definitely share the research instruments. With regard to code and data, it also depends on the nature of the code and data and the identity of the other researcher.
NA
NA
NA

There is some chance such a request may not be in good faith; for virtually any empirical test, there exists an alternative specification which can force the results to go away; a researcher whose primary interest seems to be in finding this, rather than acting in good faith, may not be one that I would cooperate with. Otherwise I see no reason not to share.

I would be more inclined to share privately and more inclined to share these items for an experimental study as compared to an archival study.  In my opinion, it is too easy to criticize authors of archival studies for the many, many choices they have to make in the process of conducting social science research. I would be suspicious of the motives behind the request.
I have shared materials with other researchers before including PhD students who have reanalyzed data. So I am basing my response on my past behavior.

I would share with most anyone. I reserve the right, depending on the academic, to withhold sharing. I have shared in the past and the researcher came back and was very rude and wrote bad things about me (accusing me of being racist even though I had shared the very expensive data). I wouldn't share with her again as I thought was completely unprofessional.

I would generally be in favor, but I would have some more question. For example, if a correction study will be put in public domain I would request to have the chance to read it first and have the authors address my comments/questions. The other reason for not going 100% is that it depends what data we are talking about (is it hand collected data that I sent hundreds of hours creating?
Part of the research process
I would not share if i had other work in progress based on the materials.
My only hesitation would be if the data were protected. I would 100% share code

It is somewhat hard to quantify this exactly, but my starting point is that material, data, code, etc. should be publicly available, so if not already available in e.g. a data repository, the only correct response would be to comply with the request. Of course, within 'reasonable limits', so if someone today would approach me about data, code, etc. from 10 years ago, I probably would be unable to comply because I simply would be unable. There might be limited instances also of proprietary data, or so, so the chance of complying isn't 100% but surely high. In practice, I've received a few (not any) of such requests and always been able to comply.
It would depend on whether there was some aspect of the study I needed to use in future studies - e.g., data that had value that would be reduced if I made it publicly available to others.
I can only imagine not sharing this if I had very bad vibes about the request...no clear explanation of why the request is made, no greeting, spelling errors, etc.
NA
NA
Cannot share data due to IRB rules.

I’d be on the fence. On one hand, I’m happy to help others and I have nothing to hide. On the other, preparing the data and code is a LOT of work and I would not want someone to “free ride.” I would expect to receive some credit for it (I.e., co-authorship).
Open science is good science.
I'm a theorist and need citations

Our job is to generate insights/knowledge. Sharing materials creates a) transparency b) protects me in case I made an error ("being forthcoming, transparent") and c) it reduces work/effort for other researchers (i.e., standing on the shoulders of giants). If we have learned one thing from the innovation literature, it is that we rely on prior research. Why make it unnecessarily hard for other to replicate results.
Sometimes code becomes IP at some point.

There might have been substantial workload flown into collecting data that also will benefit follow-up projects. Giving away the data might harm future projects without remuneration for the collection effort.
Generally I am happy to share.  There is a slight chance that I don't think their request is legitimate or made with good intentions that I might not respond positively.

I think I feel like my data, coding, and research materials are mine (i.e., I feel somewhat possessive over them), given the hundreds (if not thousands) of hours spent to generate them. It bothers me to some extent to think of someone using my materials without me knowing exactly what they're doing and without me giving my explicit permission for these materials to be used in that specific way.
Sharing of materials is generally a good idea. However, there are some purposes not worth supporting (e.g., "reverse" p-hacking).

I strongly believe in research reproducibility as being crucial to valid inferences. I also note that it is necessary but not sufficient, insofar as errors (coding, functional form, outlier treatment, deflation) will not be detected via simple replication. To the extent that people reuse my code/data, it will also increase my citation count and other measures of influence.

Code is generally proprietary, and I am hesitant to share it. I would need more information on what the researcher is working on before sharing it, and I would want to know I can trust the other researcher not to give the code out to others or use it to compete with work I am still doing. Generally it would be on the inquiring researcher to replicate code. If the research had a specific problem them couldn't solve, I would be more open to sharing pieces of code.
depends on whether i know the researcher and his/her background
NA

I would like to know the true intent of the researcher. Is it to further knowledge or show that inferences can change using different assumptions. Every study has assumptions and changing the assumptions might change the inferences. This shouldn't b surprising to anyone.
This is science, it's how we learn. And I have nothing to hide.
I don't think there is anything to hide in the data.  The party that asks has to be known and trustworthy.
I know my research will be reproducible as I am extremely meticulous about my work
I would have no problem in sharing the dataset, although I would be reluctant to provide proprietart data or survey-based data.
I typically use confidential data that I cannot share.   The programs without the data are not very useful and they can reveal confidential information, like the name of the firm.

I am open to sharing most everything. However, there is some context that might contribute to lack of trust in the request and the ultimate intent. There is definitely some variation in what researchers believe is ethical.

Data may not be shareable due to legal agreements. I already share much of my code; however, some of it is messy and may take time to clean. Also, results can be p-hacked away (e.g., much of Miguel's work)
NA
I like to encourage others to build off of my own work, but I don't like to share data if I am using that data for a follow-up study that is not yet published.
I will comply the request to the extent there is no proprietary data.
I always make supporting information available to other researchers when requested. It may help them learn our process and expand upon our work.
Sharing data and code should be strongly encouraged. I would personally love to do that except when the data collection is costly and I have another ongoing project using the same data.

If the data is extremely hard to get and I am still producing papers based on the data, I would be unlikely to share it (although I would make it clear that I would consider sharing it in the future). If I am largely done using this data I would be more likely to share it. If the data is easily available I may share it if the researcher clearly needs help (e.g., a PhD student); however, I would expect experienced researchers to be able to obtain common data easily (of course, I would consider sharing any proprietary analyses/code etc...)

The request is entirely reasonable. I am withholding a small fraction in case there were a situation where there is a conflict of interest or doubt as to whether the researcher would be able to conduct the proposed study with the appropriate rigor.

I feel strongly about reproducibility of academic research and would be glad to share materials to aid in a reproduction of my study. Additionally, a new study showing different results is equally valuable to the literature.

It takes a lot of time to develop a study, especially if hand gathering data and writing code. That's a lot of effort to hand to another person. We try to develop programs of research to aid in the publication process (for promotion and tenure decisions).

There are only three reasons I would not share. One is if the data is in some way proprietary--e.g., restricted by an NDA. The second is if I seriously questioned the integrity or intentions of the person requesting me to share. The third is if it was extremely time-consuming to comply with the request.

I would comply with the request, almost definitely. The only hesitation would be if the other researcher was known to be disingenuous in their reasoning for the project. For example, if the researcher was known to be more interested in proving prior work wrong than getting an objectively more correct answer.

Everything that the researcher needs to know should be knowable from the published paper.  I would happily respond to questions but shipping over data (which is illegal if they don't have valid access) and programs seems excessive.  They should do their own work if they want to replicate.
I try to be transparent and helpful. I have nothing to hide.
I have put a large amount of effort in collecting the data.
In principle yes, unless there are limitations to data sharing (e.g., due to a non-disclosure agreement). That's the 25% 'doubt'.

I would be willing to share the data, unless I got it from a proprierary dtatbase for whihc I paid, in whihc case I can't share it. I won't want to share the code as that is my own IP. Even handcollected data has some measure of IP in it, so I can only share it after I am finished with the data - or if the other researchers undertake not to use my data without my permission.
As long as it is a researcher from a recognized academic or professional organization I would provide the same.  So-called "independent researchers" would be judged on a case by case basis.
What is meant by "publicly" share data? If it means, sharing the data with the researcher who emailed me, then I would most likely do that. However, I may not publicly post the data on my website.

Costs of complying:  - Data/code as an intangible asset for related research projects  - Risk of adverse consequences of errors found by a potential replication study (while replication studies would mean an important benefit for any research stream as a whole, it seems that for the individual who published a paper, a replication of that particular study seems unfortunately net costly for the individual, which might work strongly against open science)
Science should move forward. If my results are wrong I would want to know so that we are aware and move forward. Occasionally being wrong, and improving past results, are all part of the process.
I believe that studies should be replicable and that we should share all information possible; however, I am concerned about sharing publicly and others taking advantage of the availability.
Proprietary or licensed data.
It depends who asked.  I would be more inclined to share data than code.
advance the field
This should go without saying. If I'm publishing something, someone should be able to look at what I did and evaluate my claims. If I made a mistake, someone should be able to point it out.

My answer would have been 100% except for two reasons: 1) I cannot share the data because it is proprietary information from a field site; 2) I am currently working on a closely related paper that employs the same data or method.

It depends on what the researcher is asking for.  For instance, data is usually license encumbered and cannot be shared in its raw form.  Furthermore, I prefer to share materials publicly rather than through private channels, and as such it takes time to set up a useful yet license-abiding data library for a project.    If it's code, I usually point to the sample code hosted on my website.    It also depends on the effort put in by the researcher.  If the researcher is asking for code but clearly doesn't understand the underlying method, I'll usually point them to resources to learn about the method first.
It is better off for our profession if everyone is willing to share resources with others.
I don't think there's enough information to answer the question. I believe without knowing who made the request, I can't make a decision.
I always share the data when asked and I try to make reproducible code available anyway. It's the right thing to do and I would expect it from other researchers as well.

Depends on the data. As a primarily qualitative research, the data I work with is oftentimes from case studies, and which tend to have requirements regarding anonymity and confidentiality. As such, I would have to process the data to turn it into such that I would be able to share. When working with public data, I would have no issues.

Research processes should be transparent, reliable, and valid. So, I have no problem with sharing them. The only reason for not saying 100% was that I do also some qualitative research. Qualitative data from some organisations cannot easily be shared because of, for example, NDAs.
Not all data can or should be made available due to confidentially agreements or ethical reasons.
I work mostly with interview data, where anynomity cannot always be guaranteed.
NA

It depends on whether the data is still used in another (unpublished) study and on who asks (whether I believe this person's intentions and integrity). For instance, if the person who asks is somebody I personally know, trust and rely on his/her abilities to analyse, interpret the data and present it in an appropriate way, I would share my data and code, however, if it is somebody I do not know well, I would not do it.

In phasing your question, it is not clear whether the data I was using were proprietary in the sense that I would be breaking my agreement by giving them to anyone who asked. If the data were mine, I would have answered 100%. The value of a good study is not the outcome but the idea. I would think any researcher would hope others would believe his/her research to be based on ideas that warrant replication and testing. Therefore, it should be the researcher's job to make sure his/her research is done carefully so it will stand the test of analysis by future scholars.
We must be able to do replications of prior work to determine whether inferences are correct and valid.
Depends on whether the data is proprietary or publicly available. Also depends on the reasons behind the request.

It depends a bit on the other researcher motivation for approaching me. It sounded to me a bit as if the person intends to build up a database and to use my material as content for the platform. I would be hesitant of that. But, in general, I am always sharing data as well as survey/experimental material upon request
Because if there is a shadow of a doubt, I pay the consequences. Moreover, I care about the results--so if they can be improved upon, I am all for it!

When collecting data, I promise respondents full anonimity and promise them that their data will be stored in a safe place and will not be shared with others. Also, I do not generally feel that others should be able to use 'my' data for their own research. On the other hand, other researchers should be allowed to verify the soundness of my analyses.
The decision depends on the other researcher's credentials and presumed reasons for the request.

Decision depends on confidentiality of the data, seriousness of the other researcher's proposal, other researcher's reputation, questionable whether additional materials need to be shared given requirements on many journals to be transparent and make data / code available
I would want more details about WHY this researcher is seeking to replicate my research.
Unless the data were confidential or there was a competitive reason (i.e., competing paper) to deny the request, I would share it.
Likely would comply
This seems like a standard request. Barring any privacy/confidentiality issues with sharing the data, I can't think of a reason not to.
NA
Verification of „goodwill“ and background check of person needed (e.g., could be data skimming attempt)
I support the replicability of studies.
Quality of previous research by the researcher requesting more information.

I am willing to share my code, but my decision regarding the data will depend on its source and cost (e.g., commercial privately bought or public but obtained at great cost) and also on whether I intend to conduct further analyses that could potentially constitute additional academic papers.
Would probably ask for the reason the researcher needs my code and data. Why not reconstruct on their own?

I conduct mainly qualitative research within an interpretive approach. From this perspective, I would be happy to provide coding details, interviewee schedules, documentation reviewed and anything that was not 'confidential'
Just so.
I would be happy to share all of my materials, data etc. and have done so in the past.
The willingness to allow data is dependent of the specific use of my research.
Transparency is key to academic progress. I did not choose 100% because there is a tendency of some people to search for errors in data and code and attack researchers in non-constructive ways.
It comes across as an incredibly rude request with an implicit assumption that the authors, reviewers and editor are "morons."
When I ask other researchers for data, they are always happy to share data with me. That's why I do the same thing. With such sharing, our academic community could develop in a heathy way.
Data may be of a proprietary/confidential nature and research ethics rules may require informants to be kept anonymous.

I would always be happy to share my code and methodology. However, not all data can be shared due to data provider requirements (e.g., data purchased from a data provider or confidential data). In those case, providing steps on how data is cleaned and prepared for econometric analyses is the best one can do.
It depends on the research asking. If this is a random researcher, i may not be inclined to share, but if this is someone from my own field, I will definitely share.

As long as the researcher complies with the stated purpose of the request, I would be willing to cooperate. However, there is always the chance of misconduct by the other researcher; thus, I would be somewhat reluctant to accept the researcher's explanation of the request.

Because ability to replicate prior studies is critical to the progress of accounting research. That said, before complying with the researcher's request I would need to understand the motivation/objectives of the request as well as the intentions of the researcher.
If the data are publicly available, it would help the researcher and save a lot of re-inventing the wheel.
I am using public data, and my work can be reproduced regardless of whether I provide mine or not.

I try to keep my data and code well organized. It's no trouble to send the final versions of stuff. It's also helpful to other researchers, and since I occasionally make the same request of others, I selfishly want to encourage norms of sharing and compliance.
Open source data can move research progress along more quickly
I would be cautious in fear of the requester's intention to steal research ideas of working papers based on the same data. Otherwise I would be happy to share the requested material.
I am usually open to giving data to reasonable requests.
I do experiments so they'd ask for the materials ...
I typically try to be transparent with my methods and materials; I'll share code and data with PhD students, but not faculty (who should do the work on their own).

It would depend on the amount of data transformation that is involved - and the concern that the researcher makes an error in replication, but is not careful enough to recheck the data several times/consult with others.
The request is reasonable.  However, the information should be available in the method section of the paper

Historically science has been a gift economy.  Proprietorship of scientific knowledge is an obstacle to scientific activity.  Every scientist has an interest in her discoveries being validated by the scientific community.  To refuse other scholars from doing that for you seems counter-productive.  Of course accounting research is not about discovery or understanding; it is about "hits" in premier journals so data bases have a value in that their withholding confirms the researcher's contention on the strength of only two reviewers -- once it is in it is "evidence" forever.
I would do this if the data is public anyhow. Often I have confidential data which would preclude me from sharing the data.
I am worried that their paper tries to attack my paper and hurt my academic reputation.

I would want to share my materials but I would be nervous that I did something "wrong" and it would make me look bad if my study didn't replicate. I'm a junior faculty and wouldn't want to do anything to jeopardize my reputation or likelihood of getting tenure.
Not 100% since there sometimes weird people with weird emails.
Unless I have another ongoing project that builds on the data, I'm willing to share my research materials.
Qualification and track record of the researcher. How do I know they have the skills to do the correct analysis?
Most likely yes, but all depends on the tone and the quality / trustworthiness of the requester.

Too often my research instruments have been used by others without attribution. Also, the number of requests from masters and doctoral students is large. Finally, my coauthors or I may be extending the study currently.     Data can be hard and expensive to collect especially from some populations such as experienced auditors. Just giving it away is a lot to ask.
Usually, sharing works to everyones advantage. However, there may be a few instances where this is not true

Currently, I perform qualitative work via interviews. Much of my work is on highly sensitive topics and I have given participants assurance (via IRB) that their transcripts will not be shared expect where a review is REQUIRED by my university or by the journal. In other words, I am not at liberty to share my data without violating the confidence and trust of my subjects.     However, if my work was a case study, or not sensitive subject matter subject to IRB stipulations, I do not mind sharing. In fact, I have shared research instruments in the past.
Licences and uniquenes of data set.
NA

It depends on whether I know the person and their reputation in the research community. I think my reputation would be tarnished if I didn't provide but I would also be skeptical of providing someone I didn't know my hand-collected data and code that took years of work to produce.
I don't mind sharing data, etc. However, it is time consuming. I would like to be sure there is an integrity behind the rquest before spending my time.
Would comply if I knew the researcher or felt I could trust the researcher.

I am open to sharing any data that I've collected when appropriate. Given I am an experimentalist, my research involves primary data that is not available to the public. I would need to obtain approval to share the data to comply with IRB/Ethics policies regarding the storage and dissemination of data collected via an experiment. I may be hesitant to share my code with an academic I do not know. Generally, the statistics I conduct are fairly straightforward so this would be an odd request. I think this may make more sense for an archivalist.
This is already happening if you publish in JAR, which I did. Our code is available on JAR’s website. Interested parties can access it and play with it.

Overall, this is important to comply with. I still can imagine that not every project I design will have public consumption in mind, so the occasional one might be difficult to be made *public*, even if  I am happy to share all on a one-to-one basis.
Happy to share (part of) my coding (e.g., dofiles) but sharing data (especially when it comes from commercial vendors) is perhaps not possible.

In most scenarios, when I can vouch for the quality of the data and the coding, I would share the research materials. When coding was not done by myself or in earlier work, where my coding was perhaps less elegant or efficient, I would perhaps prefer not to share the code (but let's say only the data) or at least not immediately.
NA

Searching the correct data file and providing/explaining the data is time consuming, therefore I do not respond to each request. Moreover, I expect additional time consuming questions and discussion when I send the raw material.  Sometimes, a follow up study is planned and I cannot offer the data (= my USP).
Data that I use typically come in the form of interviews, which are difficult to share in "raw form".
If it's proprietary data, I cannot share. If it's public data, and I would like to share.
Advancing research is aided by replication
NA
This is a requirement of most journals and the ethical thing to do.
I do not knwo the researcher hability on the method to contrapose my findings
My research is qualitative in nature so 1) they could go to archives to get the data. I also do interviews and these can't be shared as they are under ethics.

I usually would comply with the request if the intention what she/he wants to do with it is soundly explained by the requester and if there are no confidentiality reasons that might inhibit the sharing of the data (would then already have been clarified in the publication process with the journal and appropriately declared). Regarding the sharing of the research instrument there are usually no problems at all.
Nothing secret about any of it.  Unless a red flag (e.g., prior 'copy cat') i'd share
That is the right thing to do.
It is important to have high standards for research outreach and reproducibility.

The question has not distinguished between different types of reasoning processes nor the type of data and follows a hypothetical-deductive logic, where replicability is important but is only part of the available research approaches.

The other researcher can already find the relevant information to replicate my study from my paper. If there is any confusion, I’m glad to clarify. I may share data to the public if the data is not subject to non disclosure restrictions by the data vendor.
Why should I?
I have nothing to hide
The purpose of research is to better understand the world, and replication (and scrutiny) of one's research is an essential element of developing a deep understanding of the world.
S/He can get my code and my non-sensitive data. However, most of my research is based on sensitive data that can not be distributed without permission.

Science is (should be) open. If someone thinks that (s) he can build upon my study, that would only be great. Even the revision of results would not be an issue, I think, also depending upon the information that the other researcher is willing to give.     Some issues:  - I would be interested to see what the other researcher would be doing. If (s)he would focus on overthrowing previous work no matter what, that would be an issue (i.e., unethical research purpose, yet that would be difficult to grasp in a short contact);  - Similar, I would have to be able to share the data. E.g. if data was gathered through field study or survey where anonymity is guaranteed, I would not share the data;   - If I would be working on a follow-up paper with the same dataset, I would not share the dataset with the other researcher.
This is the way how science should work.
Building on my study is the most sensitive part, if I'm still in the process of generating follow up research with the same setting/data.
If  I was using the data in another study in process, I would delay sharing.
In most cases I would comply, but there are researchers out there I would not share with
Lack of faith in others’ motivation and intentions
NA

Main factors in no particular order:  1) Bandwidth - if code/data is already in format for sharing then yes, otherwise large fixed cost  2) Competitive interest - if data can be shared that does not affect publishability of existing working papers
Depends on how the other person is presenting his/her request and his/her true intentions (i.e., genuine curiosity).
I have had frivolous requests in the past.

I would detail the public datasets and the specific coding procedures/decisions, but I would hesitate to simply provide them full access to all aspects of the data and code without explanation or discussion
NA
This is simply how science is supposed to work.
It is extremely important that we raise the standards for making data and the programs used to process the data publicly available.
I would appreciate having others build on my research
If the data is not being used for further research projects then I would share it.
I do not mind any professional researcher veryfy my study, if I do not plan to write another paper based on collected data in the nearest future.
NA

I am quite happy to share materials and code. The sharing of data is dependent on whether there are any other restrictions prohibiting the sharing of data. If there are no restrictions, I may share the data if I believe the other researcher's ideas do not compete with my own ideas for using the data for future projects.
the material is my intellectual property
Would do so if data is not proprietary. Result can verified anyway
depends on type of data (proprietary data cant be shared)
I would have to understand the academic purpose of the request and the quality of the prospected research
NA
As long as the researcher was part of the accounting academic community, I would comply because sharing data etc. is part of the implicit contract we all make when conducting research
It would depend on the quality of the researcher who contacted me

I'm usually open to sharing data/code as long as the individual requesting the information is willing to disclose who they are. If the individual requesting the information chooses to remain anonymous then I am reluctant to share such information.
NA
Research is meant to expand knowledge. We need to be open to scrutiny or science won’t progress in this regard.
Depends if data are proprietary and useful for follow-on work by the same author team
My code and research design are my expertise and my ability to produce research. Giving it to someone that I do not know and that may use it in ways I do not know about seems risky.

I am all for providing an audit trail on research. But sometimes these requests are just thinly veiled ways to use someone else's effort to extract a second article out of the same data without extending coauthorship credit. This has happened to me. Collecting data takes time, and those rights need to be respected.

As a general rule, I would comply with these request. However, I can imagine some instances (requests from academics from not very well known institutions) where I would be more hesistant, fearing that it might be a scam of some sorts.
As long as it is feasible, I would help out.

It would depend if I had additional work I was planning to do. If I had created the database, I would want to ensure I received the benefits from my collection labor. I understand the need to provide data, but faculty have different time. Faculty who don't have to teach as much could get to a planned project faster than I could. I might ask the faculty what they needed it for and share it with them to accomplish their objective.
I support research replicability and even if it does not replicate in other settings we need to know. That is the premise of scienece
I mainly do qualitative research. It is not possible to share the data with others with this type of research (agreements with the participants).
Move the literature forward and increase the visibility of my own work.
